channel.title: Comments on: Some thoughts on Israel’s law, the Gentiles, and Christ

item.title: By: Richard Barcellos
item.dc:creator: Richard Barcellos
item.description: That is a tough text to get around. Both Jews and Greeks are “under the law” and therefore guilty before God. The only way that this can be possible is if the law the Jews are under and the law the Greeks are under correspond at least to a degree.
item.content:encoded: That is a tough text to get around. Both Jews and Greeks are “under the law” and therefore guilty before God. The only way that this can be possible is if the law the Jews are under and the law the Greeks are under correspond at least to a degree.

item.title: By: Andrew Suttles
item.dc:creator: Andrew Suttles
item.description:
Thanks Dr. B., and others -
Rom 3:19 is, in particular, extremely compelling. I'd like to know how a dispensationalist would get around that one.
Andrew
item.content:encoded:
Thanks Dr. B., and others –

Rom 3:19 is, in particular, extremely compelling. I’d like to know how a dispensationalist would get around that one.

Andrew

item.title: By: Ron Miller
item.dc:creator: Ron Miller
item.description: Thank you for more good stuff on this sadly misunderstood issue of the Christian and the moral law. Incontrovertible (it's fun to say that word, isn't it?).
item.content:encoded: Thank you for more good stuff on this sadly misunderstood issue of the Christian and the moral law. Incontrovertible (it’s fun to say that word, isn’t it?).

item.title: By: Rich B.
item.dc:creator: Rich B.
item.description: I agree with Noble. There's a new book out - From the Finger of God - which shows, among many other things, that pre-Sinai ethics assume laws which end up pomulgated by God on stone tablets and by Moses in Ex. and Deut.
item.content:encoded: I agree with Noble. There’s a new book out – From the Finger of God – which shows, among many other things, that pre-Sinai ethics assume laws which end up pomulgated by God on stone tablets and by Moses in Ex. and Deut.
